title: 105_hr530
content: The Criminal Welfare Prevention Act, Part II, addresses the treatment of prisoners under Titles II and XVI of the Social Security Act. The Criminal Welfare Prevention Act, Part II, amends Section 202(x)(3) of the Social Security Act to prohibit the payment of Title II benefits to prisoners. The Commissioner must enter into agreements with jails, prisons, and other institutions confining individuals to provide necessary information monthly. The Commissioner requires institutions to provide identifying information about confined individuals for the purpose of stopping Title II benefit payments to prisoners. The institution will receive $400 for each individual whose benefits cease due to this provision if the information is provided within 30 days. The Commissioner requires institutions to provide identifying information about confined individuals to stop Title II benefit payments to prisoners. The institution will receive $400 for each individual if the information is provided within 30 days, or $200 if provided within 90 days. No payment will be made if benefits are already stopped before receiving the information. Payment amounts will be reduced by 50% if the Commissioner is also required to make a payment under a different agreement. The agreement allows the Commissioner to transfer funds from the Trust Funds to make payments to institutions for providing information on confined individuals. The Commissioner can also share this information with other federal assistance programs for eligibility purposes on a reimbursable basis. The Act applies to individuals starting confinement after four months from enactment. Title II requirement for confinement stemming from a crime punishable by over 1 year is eliminated. The amendment changes the language to refer to a criminal offense instead. The amendment eliminates the requirement for confinement related to crimes punishable by over 1 year, changing the language to refer to a criminal offense. The effective date applies to individuals starting confinement after four months from enactment. The amendment modifies sections of the Social Security Act related to payment preclusion under Title XVI. It updates references to specific sections and applies amendments retroactively to align with previous enactments. The amendment to the Social Security Act modifies payment preclusion under Title XVI by specifying that no payment shall be made to an institution for information on an inmate if the Commissioner determines the inmate is no longer eligible. The Social Security Act amendment includes a 50% reduction in Title XVI payments if a comparable Title II payment is involved. It also expands the categories of institutions eligible to enter into agreements with the Commissioner. The Social Security Act amendment expands the categories of institutions eligible to enter into agreements with the Commissioner, allowing for agreements with jails, prisons, penal institutions, or correctional facilities. Payment limitations are also placed on certain categories of inmates. The Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to include individuals eligible for benefits while in jail or prison. Technical corrections are also made to the Act. The amendments apply as if included in the original enactment. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to include individuals eligible for benefits while incarcerated. Technical corrections are made to the Act, and exemptions from computer matching requirements are specified. The Social Security Act is amended to include individuals eligible for benefits while incarcerated. Technical corrections are made to the Act, and exemptions from computer matching requirements are specified. The amendments made by this subsection shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act.
